column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=2.
#Text=Description of the Related Art
#Text=A typical oilfield well comprises several strings or tubing, such as casing strings.
#Text=FIG. 1 illustrates one particular conventional well.
#Text=The illustrated well includes a casing head 10 supporting an outer casing string 15.
#Text=A casing hanger 20 is landed in the casing head 10 and supports an inner or production casing string 25.
#Text=A tubing head 30 is disposed above the casing head 10.
#Text=During normal production operations, the tubing head 30 supports a tubing hanger (not shown) and production tubing (also not shown).
#Text=The production casing string 25 extends downward into a hydrocarbon bearing formation 35.
#Text=It is common in oilfield production operations to "workover" a slow producing or marginal well to stimulate and increase production.
#Text=Such workover techniques may include high-pressure fracturing of the formation 35, known to the art as "fracing" a well or formation.
#Text=It is also common to fracture a new well to increase the production capability of the well.
#Text=Generally, in this process, a sand-bearing slurry is pumped down into the formation at very high pressures.
#Text=The sand particles become embedded in small cracks and fissures in the formation, wedging them open and, thus, increasing the flow of produced fluid.
#Text=Such fracturing processes are typically more efficient at lower portions of the wellbore 40.
#Text=For example, as illustrated in FIG. 1, fluid may be pumped into the production casing 25, achieving an efficient fracture of the lowest zone 45.
#Text=A bridge plug 50 may then be installed above the lowest zone 45, after which the well is fractured again, achieving an efficient fracture of the middle zone 55.
#Text=A second bridge plug 60 may then be installed above the middle zone 55, after which the well is once again fractured, achieving an efficient fracture of the upper zone 65.
#Text=The bridge plugs 50, 60 are typically installed using a wireline lubricator.
#Text=While three zones (e.g., the zones 45, 55, 65) are illustrated in FIG. 1, any number of zones may be identified in a well and any number of fracturing cycles may be performed.

#Text=The tubing head 30 and any valves associated with the tubing head, such as a valve 70 in FIG. 1, are typically rated for the expected formation pressure, i.e., the pressure of fluids produced from the well.
#Text=The fracturing pressure, however, is typically much higher than the formation pressure and often exceeds the pressure rating of the tubing head and valves.
#Text=Moreover, the fluids used during fracturing are often very abrasive and/or corrosive.
#Text=Therefore, the tubing head 30 and other such components of the top flange connection 78 are often isolated and protected from the fracturing fluid by a wellhead isolation tool 75.

#Text=A conventional wellhead isolation tool 75 mounts above a frac tree assembly 80 and comprises an elongated, tubular stab that passes through the tubing head 30 and seals to the inside surface of the production casing 25.
#Text=The fracturing fluid may then be pumped through the wellhead isolation tool 75, bypassing the tubing head 30 and frac tree assembly 80.

#Text=Thus, the flange connections between the tubing head 30, the frac tree assembly 80 and tubing head annulus gate valves 70 are isolated from the pressure and the abrasive/corrosive characteristics of the fracturing fluid.
